fileheader.author: Anders Gidenstam
fileheader.description: Model of the Zeppelin LZ 129 Hindenburg.

reference.author: Manfred Bauer and John Duggan
reference.title: LZ 130 Graf Zeppelin und das Ende der Verkehrsluftschiffahrt

reference.author: Eugen Bentele
reference.title: The Story of a Zeppelin Mechanic

reference.author: Hugh B. Freeman
reference.title: Force Measurements on a 1/40-scale Model of the U.S. Airship ``Akron''; NACA Report #432

metrics.documentation: NOTE: The origo of the structural/body coordinate system is at the mooring mast coupling at center of the bow. x/y/z = back/right/up

mass_balance.documentation:
Mass distribution data [Bauer:1992:LZ130].
Based on a list of weight savings in the empty weight of LZ 130 over LZ 129 (page 74). All weights (masses) are in kg. The numbers for LZ 129 are inferred based on the listed savings.
Article LZ 130 saving LZ 129 Gerippe, Leitwerk, ruder 55460 908 56368 X Hulle m. Anstrich u. Verkleidung 7924 1095 9019 X Zellenanlage 12895 131 13026 X Maschinenanlage[1] 20520 -4819 15701 X Elektrische u. F.T.-Anlage 3746 1214 3960 Betriebstoffanlage[2] 2333 2333 Wasseranlage[2] 1422 1422 Apparate, Zuge, etc 257 257 Verankerung 915 915 X Fuhrergondel u. Steueranlage 1281 -81 1200 X Fahrgastraume 6262 4346 10608 X Betriebsraume 1445 511 1956
Total 114460 3305 117765
X Accounted for in the model. [1] LZ 130 was equipped for water reclamation from the exhaust. [2] I assume this is the empty weight of the tanks and pipes.

The empty weight is estimated to consist of The structural parts (Gerippe, Leitwerk, ruder) 56368 The hull covering (Hulle m. Anstrich und Verkleidung) 9019 The (empty) gas cells (Zellenanlage) 13026
The other items in the list above will be represented by point masses.

% Very rough estimation model of the empty weight CG and inertia tensor. % Assume the empty weight of is to 60% a cylindrical shell and % to 40% a thin rod (i.e. the keel). % The keel is located r meters below the centrum line.
m = 78413.0 % KG r = 20.0 % meter l = 245 % meter
% Very rough estimate of center of gravity (based on the inertial estimate): CGx = l / 2 CGy = 0 CGz = - 1/6 * pi * r
% Steiner's theorem: % Ixx = \bar{Ixx} + m sqrt(\bar{y}^2 + \bar{z}^2) % Ixy = \bar{Ixy} + m \bar{x} \bar{y}
% Very rough estimation model of Ixx, Iyy and Izz relative the CG. Ixx = (0.6*m) * r^2 + (0.6*m) * 1/6 * pi * r + \ (0.4*m) * r * (1 - 1/6*pi)
Iyy = 1/2*(0.6*m) * r^2 + 1/12*(0.6*m)*l^2 + (0.6*m) * 1/6 * pi * r + \ 1/12*(0.4*m)*l^2 + (0.4*m) * r * (1 - 1/6*pi)
Izz = 1/2*(0.6*m) * r^2 + 1/12*(0.6*m)*l^2 + \ 1/12*(0.4*m) * l^2
Ixy = 0 Ixz = 0 Iyz = 0
The engine weight according to [Bentele:1992:SZM] is 2200 kg excluding the cooler. The total weight of the engine installations in the list above indicates a weight of 3925.2 kg per engine.

"... 23 Beh\"alter mit 40_000 Liter Gesamt-Inhalt f\"ur Frisch- und Abwasser..." [Tittel:1997:LZ129] "S\"amtliche Wasserf\"asser sind mit Schnellentlerungsventilen (50 l/s.) ausger\"ustet." [Tittel:1997:LZ129] (")

propulsion.documentation:
Engine data from [Bentele:1992:SZM].
Manufacturer: Daimler Bentz AG Type: LOF 6 (DB 602) (Diesel) No. cylinders: V 16 Max power: 1050 HP Max rpm: 1500 rpm Cruise power: 940 HP Cruise rpm: 1350 rpm Swept volume: 88 dm3 Weight (w/o cooler): 2200 kg Power/weight ration: 2.8 kg/kWh Fuel consumption (cruise): 0.225 kg/kWh Piston diameter: 175 mm Piston stroke: 230 mm Compression ration: 1:16 Reduction gear: 2:1 Propeller diameter: 6.0 m Propeller rpm (cruise): 625 rpm
Notes: 2 input, 2 output valves. No supercharger. Could rotate in either direction. Compressed air starter.

Engine data from [Bauer:1992:LZ130].
Daimler Bentz LOF 6 Max power: 885 kW (1200 HP) at 1600 rpm Cruise power: 660 kW (900 HP) at 1400 rpm
Diesel consumption: max 245 g/kWh (180 g/HPh) Lub. oil consumption: max 4 g/kWh (3 g/HPh)
Total diesel fuel: ca 80000 dm^3 Total lub. oil: ca 4500 dm^3

NOTE: Reversing of the engine is simulated by rotating the thruster 180 degrees around the yaw (z) axis. NOTE: The fuel system is incomplete - each engine should feed from a local feeder tank located inside the hull above it. These tanks were in turn fed from the tanks along the keel in a manner controlled by the crew.
NOTE: The capacity numbers were given in liters. The density of diesel is 0.850kg/liter.
